description:
A stick of deep-fried dough, basically a long doughnut, listed variously in English as *Chinese cruller*, *Chinese doughnut*, [Chinese churro](https://medium.com/@pandacheffy/recipe-how-to-cook-chinese-food-youtiao-churro-cruller-74313b5c3a4c) (pretty similar), by the Mandarin pronunciation [youtiao]((https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Youtiao), and, a directly translation of the Mandarin name), *oil stick*.

Typically served at breakfast with congee or soy milk, sometimes cut into short segments for convenience when serving.

**Characters**

The Cantonese name [油炸鬼](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E6%B2%B9%E7%82%B8%E9%AC%BC) is *oil fried ghost* ([油](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E6%B2%B9) is *oil*, [炸](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%82%B8) is *deep-fried*, and [鬼](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E9%AC%BC) is *ghost*), so there's a [story](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Youtiao) behind that.

The Mandarin name just consists of [油](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E6%B2%B9), which is *oil*, and [條](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E6%A2%9D), which is *strip* (like bacon strip), so [油條](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E6%B2%B9%E6%A2%9D) is *oil strip*.

[條](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E6%A2%9D) is also the classifier for long thin items, so for example to order one strip of fried dough, you'd specify in Cantonese 一條油炸鬼 (yāt tíu yàuh ja gwái) *one strip of oil deep-fried ghost* or ,somewhat redundantly in Mandarin, 一條油條 (yī tiáo yóu tiáo) *one strip of oil strip*

Rice roll wrapped around fried dough. Often served with porridge.

**Characters**

[炸](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%82%B8) means *deep-fried* and [兩](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%82%B8) means *two* (as in a *couple of*) so [炸兩](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%82%B8%E5%85%A9) means *deep-fried twice*.
